Translation of 郭店楚簡-緇衣(en) into English.

p.seg: Our master said:
if (the ruler) loves beauty like he loves the black robe
and hates ugliness like he hates the elder of the lane,
then the people will all do their outmost
and the model will not move.
The Poetry says:
“You should (now) make king Wen your pattern;
all the states will then have confidence.”
The master said:
“If the holders of states display what they like and what they dislike,
to show (their) people generosity,
then the people’s feelings will not be flawed.”
The Poetry says:
“Quietly respectful in your official positions,
love those correct and straight ones.”
The master said:
“if (the ruler) above can be looked upon and understood,
and [what is said by] (the ministers) below can be reported and assessed,
then the ruler will not doubt his ministers,
and the ministers will not be confused about the ruler.”
The Poetry says:
“the good man, my lord,
his fine demeanor is without fault.”
The edict of Yin says:
“It is only Yi Yin who reached to Tang,
they both had unique virtue.”
The master said:
“If the man above is hesitant,
then the common people will be confused;
if those below are hard to know
then the ruler and superiors will be troubled.
Therefore, if the ruler of the people displays what he likes
thereby showing to the people his desires,
and is cautious about what he dislikes
thereby dispelling the people’s licentiousness,
then the people will not be perplexed.
If a minister in serving his ruler
states that of which he is not capable
and does not decline that of which he is capable,
then the ruler will not be troubled.”
The Da Ya says:
“God on High is very grand;
but the lower people are utterly exhausted.”
The Xiao Ya says:
“It is not the case that they are proper in their demeanor and respect,
it is the case that they are the king’s grief.”
The master said:
“The people take the ruler as their heart
and the ruler takes the people as his limbs.
If the heart is good then the limbs find rest in it,
and if the ruler is good then the people desire him.
Therefore, as the heart is laid waste by the limbs,
so the ruler is done away with by the people.”
The Poetry says:
“Who holds the ordering of the state?
If you do not yourself effect the government,
you will cause the people suffering and toil.”
The “Lord Ya” says:
“As for the sultry rain of summer,
the petty people do daily resent it,
and as for the brisk cold of the extreme of winter,
it is also that the petty people daily resent it.”
The master said:
“if the superior loves humanness,
then among the inferiors those who act humanely
will compete to come to the fore.
Therefore, if those who head the people display their will
in order to shine upon the common people,
then the people will come to conduct themselves
so as to please their superior.”
The Poetry says:
“Straight in (his) virtuous conduct,
the states of the four quarters obey him.”
The Master said:
‘When Yu had been in position three years,
the common people were led with humaneness;
how would it have been necessary for all of them to be humane?”
The Poetry says:
“King Cheng’s sincerity
is the model of the land below.”
The “Lü xing” says:
“If the one man enjoys happiness,
then the ten-thousand people rely on him.”
The Master said:
“As for the inferiors’ serving of their superior,
they do not follow the principles by means of which he commands them,
but follow what he enacts.
If the superior loves this thing,
among the inferiors there will certainly be those who are more extreme about it.
Therefore, about the superior’s loves and hates;
one must be careful
he is the standard of the people.
The Poetry says:
“So splendid is Captain Yin,
the people all look to you.”
The Master said:
“If he who heads the people does not change his clothing
and if his countenance is constant,
then the people’s virtue will be unified.”
The Poetry says:
“His countenance does not change,
and the words he utters can be followed,
he is who the black haired people trust.”
The Master said:
“If the gentleman does not treat as intimates those whom he regards as worthy
but trusts those upon whom he looks down,
the instruction will thereby be lost
and the people will thereby change (for the worse).”
The Poetry says:
“He seeks my measure.
If he does not get me,
he holds fast to me, enemy fashion,
and yet he cannot force me.”
The “Jun Chen” says:
“Having not yet seen a sage,
it is as if it cannot be seen;
after I have seen him,
I still do not follow him as a sage.”
The Master said:
“If the great ministers are not treated as intimates,
then their loyalty and respect will not be sufficient
while their wealth and honor will already be in excess.
If the country and families are not at peace,
then the great ministers will not rule
while the sycophantic ministers will be entrusted.
This is why the great ministers must be respected;
they are the signal-pole of the people.
Therefore if the ruler does not join with the petty (people) to plot great (affairs),
then the great ministers will not be resentful.”
The “Retrospective Command of the Duke of Zhai” says:
“Do not on account of petty plots defeat great undertakings;
do not on account of favored concubines obstruct the queen;
do not on account of favored men wound the great officers and officials.”
The Master said:
“If the one who heads the common people
instructs them with virtue
and regulates them with ritual,
then the people will have a sense of encouragement;
if he instructs them with government
and regulates them with punishment,
then the people will have a sense of avoidance.
Therefore, if he cherishes them with affection,
then the people will have intimacy;
if he joins them with trust,
then the people will not turn their backs;
if he looks upon them with respect,
then the people will have a sense of compliance.”
The Poetry says:
The Master said:
“If the government is not enacted
and the instruction is not perfected,
then punishments and fines will not suffice to shame
and entitlements will not suffice to encourage.
Therefore, the superior cannot be (too) familiar with punishments
nor treat lightly entitlements.”
The “Pronouncement of Kang” says:
“respectfully make clear your fines.”
The “Punishments of Lü” says:
“Publicize the enactment of punishments.”
The Master said:
“The king’s sayings are like silk; their utterance is like a fishing line.
The king’s sayings are like a rope; their utterance is like a lasso. Therefore, the Great Man does not take the lead in rumors.”
The Poetry says:
“Be cautious of the speech you utter, be respectful in your demeanor.”
The Master said:
“If something can be said but it cannot be enacted
the gentleman does not say it,
and if something can be enacted but it cannot be said
the gentleman does not enact it;
then the people’s words will not endanger their actions,
and their actions will not endanger their words.”
The Poetry says:
“Be well careful of where you stop.
Do not be flawed in your propriety.”
The Master said:
“The gentleman leads people with words
and makes them constant with actions.
Therefore, if with words one considers where they will end,
and with actions one investigates what makes them worn-out,
then the people will be cautious with words
and circumspect in action.”
The Poetry says:
“So beautiful was king Wen,
with continuous brightness and respectful demeanor.”
The Master said:
“If words follow the enacting of them,
then actions cannot be hidden.
Therefore, if the gentleman is considerate in his words
and only then he acts,
in order to make complete his trust,
then the common people will not be able to exaggerate what is beautiful
or to trivialize what is hateful.”
The Da Ya says:
The white pendant’s blemish,
can still be polished.
“This word’s flaw,
cannot be treated.”
The Xiao Ya says:
“truly, they are noblemen;
The Master said:
“The gentleman’s words have substance,
and his actions have a pattern.
This is why while alive he cannot be deprived of his will
and when dead cannot be deprived of his name.
Therefore, the gentleman hearing much
regulates and maintains it;
remembering much
regulates and makes it intimate;
and knowing clearly
regulates it and puts it into action.”
The Poetry says:
“A fine man is the gentleman,
his propriety is unified.”
The “Jun Chen” says:
The Master said:
“If there is a cart,
you will certainly see its canopy;
if there is a jacket,
you will certainly see its striped ornaments;
if a man has words,
you will certainly hear their sounds;
and if he has actions,
you will certainly see their effects.”
The Poetry says:
“[The clothes are not old], I shall wear them without (ever) growing weary (of them).”
The Master said:
“Private kindness, when it does not embrace virtue,
a gentleman does not himself remain in it (=he refutes immoral favors)”
The Poetry says:
“Other’s liking us,
shows us the actions of Zhou.”
The Master said:
“Only a gentleman is able to love his adversaries;
how could a petty man be able to love his adversaries.
Therefore, there are tendencies as for who the gentleman befriends,
and there are methods as for who he hates.
This is why those near him are not confused
and those far away are not suspicious.”
The Poetry says:
“The lord’s loving mate.”
The Master said:
“If one treats as a light matter cutting himself off from the poor
and lowly but treats as a heavy matter cutting himself off from the rich and noble,
then his love of humanity is not firm
and his hatred of evil is not manifest.
Even if others should say that this is not to act (just) in view of profit,
I would still not believe it.”
The Poetry says:
“The way the guests are assisted;
they are assisted with a dignified demeanor.”
The Master said:
“The men of Song have a saying which goes:
‘If a man does not have constancy,
he cannot be a turtle shell or milfoil diviner.’
This must be a saying handed down from antiquity!
If even the turtle shell or milfoil do not let him know (their counsel),
how much more so is it with men! (=such a person could not be a good intermediary between the king and the people)”
The Poetry says:
“Our turtle shells being tired,
do not tell us their counsel.”
